ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: General philosophy notes and psychological studies--very interesting class!

I learned a lot about the psychology of morality, including: reason and emotion, how morality develops over childhood, universal domains of morality, how identity plays into moral judgments, and more. I also learned some philosophy, including diver deeper into utilitarianism and deontology, though the class was mostly focused on psychology.
Fascinating and interesting research on moral and developmental psychology.
I learnt a lot about moral philosophy and psychology, and how different schools of thought can be considered to answer the question of how to be good.

The psychology behind human (adult and child) morality. The factors we consider as relevant in these decisions, and how that varies across age, gender, ethnicity/race/nationality, and even political party.
a

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: well-organized, super interesting material, enthusiastic professor and TF, and the writing assignments were helpful for assimilating information

Weaknesses: an unwieldy amount of video lectures (particularly if you're taking a second class), received feedback on assignments really late (this was on the TF, not on Prof. Bloom)
Better and quicker feedback from the TF's.
This was a great course! Content was very engaging, discussions were interesting, and Professor Bloom is incredible.

Strengths is materials. Weakness is that I wish we had more than one hour a week with Dr. Bloom because its is interesting to see what he thinks. The TF sections allowed for more engaging and at depth discussions I wish we had with Prof. Bloom

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, worth it for discussions!

Yes, I would. The conversations are really good and the class uses fun activities to get you thinking. The class time is short so it doesn't feel too draining. The readings are a lot, but you don't usually have to know them in-depth to participate. Grading is weird though, which sucks, but not to the extent that you would have to worry about failing or anything.
Yes absolutely. Great way to better understand what morality is and how people across the world conceive of it differently
Yes, this is a great way to learn more about morality, as a psychologist or philosopher or student but also just as a human being.
Yes, incredibly exciting course!
Yes! Professor Bloom is amazing, it is a great class that doesn't have a very heavy workload, and actually changed a lot of my worldviews and how I consider some of the topics we discussed.

It definitely is not as interpretative as you think morality is, they seem to be wanting a specific response that comes from the reading and youre not really supposed to challenge it outside of the materials

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I intend to study psychology and this class covered themes that are relevant in many areas of psychology (e.g. the idea that we are born with innate structures designed to take input from the environment).
This is very exciting, I'd recommend it to everyone!
This course gave me a lot of insights and forced me to consider decision making that I normally take for granted more seriously, and it will better inform by  views on morality going forward.
Very knowledgeable especially when it comes to the topic of having an early emerging moral coresuper interesting discussion and you can tell he is deeply invested in his field
